0.text:
It's not often that you see a gravestone with
a correction on it.

3.text:
But then, it's not often that you find a story
as strange as this one.

7.text: I'm just outside Huelva, in southern Spain,

9.text:
and a little distance away is the grave of
the Man Who Never Was.

14.text: In 1943, as the Second World War raged on,

17.text:
the body of Major William Martin, of the British
Royal Marines,

20.text: was discovered floating off the coast here.

23.text:
Chained to him was a briefcase, and in it:
a letter with details about

26.text:
the Allied armies' plans to attack Greece
across the Mediterranean Sea.

30.text: It wasn't 'here are all our secret war plans',

33.text:
but it was close; it was a friendly letter
between generals

35.text: that gave away all the necessary details.

38.text:
British Intelligence raced to recover the
briefcase

41.text: before German spies could look through it,

45.text: Yes, Britain got its documents back:

47.text:
but not before a copy of them was on its way
to Hitler,

49.text:
who then moved huge numbers of troops, tanks
and boats to Greece,

54.text: ready to repel the British attack.

56.text: Hitler was probably quite surprised, then,

61.text: off the southern coast of Italy, and not Greece.

63.text:
And won, with a fraction of the losses that
they could have suffered.

67.text: There never was any Major William Martin.

71.text: But there was a man called Glyndwr Michael.

73.text: He was a Welshman in London in World War 2,

78.text: He died on the streets after eating poison;

80.text:
perhaps deliberately, perhaps by desperately
eating food that was left out for rats.

88.text:
his body was "removed out of England", and
well, that's true:

92.text: his body was held in a mortuary for a while,

94.text:
then dressed in the correct uniform and given
painstakingly forged personal documents:

98.text:
a receipt for a wedding ring, a photo and
love letter from a fiancée,

102.text: a bus ticket, some keys, some other paperwork.

104.text:
Then the body was put onboard a submarine
which sailed to the coast of Spain.

109.text: And quietly, on a dark night in April 1943,

113.text:
the boat's crew let the body drift with the
currents.

116.text:
The plan was called, rather gruesomely, Operation
Mincemeat.

120.text:
British Intelligence had chosen their target
well.

122.text: Spain had plenty of German spies,

123.text:
and the Spanish head of intelligence was the
sort of man

126.text: who would claim the discovery as his own,

128.text:
and then travel to Berlin to deliver copies
personally,

131.text:
and perhaps even embellish the story of how
it was found

134.text:
to make himself look better and the tip a
bit seem more credible.

139.text:
And of course, all the desperate British efforts
to recover the documents were a sham.

144.text:
And by 1943, the team at Bletchley Park had
cracked the Enigma cypher

149.text: and were listening to German communications:

151.text:
less than a month after Glyndwr's body had
been released,

154.text:
the codebreakers intercepted a signal that
showed that the scheme had worked perfectly.

159.text:
Britain took Sicily, used it as a beachhead
to get to Italy,

163.text: and German war plans were in tatters.

165.text:
Major Martin, by then, had been buried with
full military honours and an appropriate gravestone.

171.text: The truth was still top secret.

172.text:
It wasn't until decades later that his real
identity was revealed:

176.text: and so the grave was corrected.

179.text: Glyndwr Michael, served as Major William Martin.
